profileText: A Senator from Indiana; born in Indianapolis, Ind., December 31, 1858; attended the public schools and Butler University, Indianapolis, Ind.; served with the Indianapolis Journal as reporter, editor, part owner, and publisher 1878-1903; member, State senate 1896-1900; member, Republican National Committee 1900-1912, chairman 1907-1908; captain and assistant adjutant general in the Seventh Army Corps during the Spanish-American War; engaged in the stone quarrying and construction business; elected as a Republican to the United States Senate and served from March 4, 1917, to March 3, 1923; unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1922; chairman, Committee on Territories (Sixty-sixth Congress), Committee on Territories and Insular Possessions (Sixty-seventh Congress); appointed Postmaster General in the Cabinet of President Warren Harding in 1923; reappointed by President Calvin Coolidge in 1925 and served until 1929; retired from active business pursuits and resided in Washington, D.C.; United States Commissioner, Century of Progress Exposition, Chicago, Ill., 1933; died in Baltimore, Md., May 9, 1937; interment in the Crown Hill Cemetery, Indianapolis, Ind.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: McMains, Howard F., ed. "Booth Tarkington and the League of Nations: Advice for Senator Harry S. New.'' Indiana Magazine of History 84 (December 1988): 343-52.

researchRecord.name: Correspondence in James Orin Murfin papers, 1896-1940; William Butts Mershon papers, 1848-1943; Benjamin Sawtell Hanchett papers, 1888-1958; and William Alfred Comstock papers, 1899-1949. Finding aid.

Correspondence in League of Women Voters of Indiana records, 1910-ongoing; John Pemberton Goodwin papers, 1816-1969; Henry Smith Lane papers, 1788-1936; Judah-Brandon family papers, 1820-1950; Carleton Buel McCulloch papers, 1933-1946; and Martha Ellis Hopkins papers, 1914-1952.
58 items (1887-1933); and correspondence in Ernest Irving Lewis papers, 1897-1944.
February 26, 1929. 1 letter. To Cyril Clems concerning commemorative stamp for Mark Twain.
Items in Richard Lieber papers, 1892-1958 (bulk 1933-1944); James Flynn Stutesman papers, 1868-1916; Will H. Hays papers, 1857-1954 (bulk 1914-1954); and photographs.
Correspondence in Charles W. Fairbanks papers, 1819-1939; and Marcus Dickey papers, 1872-1941.
